poetic_form.description: The Fresh Castle is a reflective poetic form intended to describe immortality, originating in The Dented Merchant. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is five sexains. Use of elision and epenthesis is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning. Each line has four feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic tetrameter). Every line of the poem has an initial caesura. The sixth line of each sexain uses the same placement of allusions as the fifth line. The third line of each sexain reverses the grammatical structure of the first line. The rhyme scheme of the poem is AABCCC.

The Turquoise Finger is a reflective poetic form intended to teach a moral lesson concerning Onget Rockscrested, originating in The Dented Merchant. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is two to four sexains. Use of ambiguity is characteristic of the form. Each line has four syllables. The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme, though the rhyming doesn't have to be perfect. The fifth line of each sexain contrasts the underlying meaning of the first line. The sixth line of each sexain uses the same placement of allusions as the fourth line.

The Droplet of Listening is a poetic form intended to praise the past, originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is six octets. Use of internal rhyme, assonance and consonance is characteristic of the form. Each line has four feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed (qualitative trochaic tetrameter). The sixth line of each octet presents a different view of the subject of the second line. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABCCBCAA.

The Adorable Meditation is a dramatic poetic form intended to renounce, originating in The Dented Merchant. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into five to seven tercets and a line. Use of consonance and metaphor is characteristic of the form. Each line has three feet with an accent pattern of stressed-stressed (qualitative spondaic trimeter). [B]The first part concerns the past. Certain lines present different views of the same subject. The second line of each tercet must expand the idea of the first line. The rhyme scheme within each stanza is abb. As a rule throughout the poem, the end rhymes don't generally match perfectly. [B]The second part concerns the future.

The Euphoric Papers is a poetic form concerning someone's character, originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into three distinct parts: a line, two couplets and two to three quintains. Use of elision is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures. [B]The first part is intended to express pleasure with the subject of the poem. It has three feet with a syllable weight pattern of long-short (quantitative trochaic trimeter). [B]The second part is intended to develop the previous idea. Certain lines use the same placement of allusions. The second line of each couplet presents a different view of the subject of the first line. It has lines with three feet with a syllable weight pattern of long-long (quantitative spondaic trimeter). The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme. [B]The third part is intended to move away from previous ideas. The fifth line of each quintain uses the same placement of allusions as the fourth line. The fifth line of each quintain presents a different view of the subject of the third line. It has lines with three feet with a syllable weight pattern of long-short (quantitative trochaic trimeter). The rhyme scheme within each stanza is aaaba.

The Climax of Torches is a poetic narrative concerning immortality, originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single couplet. Use of vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. Each line has three feet with a syllable weight pattern of short-short-long (quantitative anapaestic trimeter). The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme. The second line of the couplet must expand the idea of the first line. The first line is intended to make an assertion. The second line is intended to undercut the previous assertion.

The Lilac of Intricacy is a light poetic form intended to renounce, originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is four to five quatrains. Use of internal rhyme is characteristic of the form. Each line has five syllables. The fourth line of each quatrain uses the same placement of allusions as the first line. The fourth line of each quatrain reverses the grammatical structure of the third line. The second line of each quatrain must expand the idea of the first line. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABBA.

musical_form.description: The Fortuitous Smile is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on three angrir and a orrun. The musical voices are purely rhythmic. It is performed without preference for a scale and in the lanlar rhythm. [B]Each angrir always provides the rhythm and should perform sweetly. [B]The orrun always provides the rhythm and should bring a sense of motion. [B]The Fortuitous Smile has a well-defined multi-passage structure: an introduction and a theme, a bridge-passage and a series of variations on the theme possibly all repeated. [B]The introduction is at a walking pace, and it is to start loud then be immediately soft. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The theme gradually slows as it comes to an end, and it is to be soft. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The bridge-passage accelerates as it proceeds, and it is to be very loud. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The series of variations is very fast, and it is to be very loud. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The lanlar rhythm is made from two patterns: the gstang and the berim. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The gstang rhythm is a single line with three beats. The beats are named libash (spoken li), lakish (la) and asdos (as). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The berim rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into eight bars in a 4-4-4-4-4-4-4-4 pattern. The beats are named ibruk (spoken ib), ermis (erm), thoth (tho) and thatthil (tha). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x - | x - - - | x - - - | x`x x - | - - x x | - x - - | x - - - | x - x`- | [B]where ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Mauve Flutes is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on a birir, a akrul and a absam. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance is at a hurried pace. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed without preference for a scale and in free rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to make trills, alternate tension and repose and play staccato. [B]The birir always does the main melody. The voice stays in the strident high register. [B]The akrul always provides the rhythm. [B]The absam always provides the rhythm. [B]The Mauve Flutes has a simple structure: a passage. [B]The simple passage should evoke tears, and it is to be in whispered undertones. The passage should be performed using frequent modulation.

The Glitter of Drumming is a devotional form of music originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on a ber, a odot and a ostest. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. Never more than an interval sounds at once. It is performed using the ogo scale and in the ung rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to make trills and syncopate. [B]The ber always provides the rhythm and should bring a sense of motion. [B]The odot always does the main melody, should be fiery and plays arpeggios. [B]The ostest always does the main melody and should feel mysterious. [B]The Glitter of Drumming has the following structure: a lengthy introduction and a passage. [B]The introduction is very slow, and it is to fade into silence. The odot stays in the wavering low register and the ber stays in the fragile middle register. The passage has mid-length phrases in the melody. The passage should be performed using frequent modulation. [B]The simple passage is consistently slowing, and it is to be moderately loud. The odot covers its entire range from the wavering low register to the strained high register and the ber ranges from the fragile middle register to the raspy high register. The passage has long phrases in the melody. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1-x-x-x-x--x-xx--x-x-x-xO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The ogo pentatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 5th, the 7th and the 8th. [B]The ung rhythm is made from two patterns: the ost and the nuklat. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The ost rhythm is a single line with five beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x X x - x | [B]where X marks an accented beat, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The nuklat rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into six bars in a 2-8-4-7-5-6 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | x X - x x - - x | - ! x x`| x X x - x - x | x x - X - | - - x - - - | [B]where ! marks the primary accent, X marks an accented beat, ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Lutes of Blossoming is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on a um and one to four ber. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance should be spirited. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. Never more than an interval sounds at once. [B]The um always provides the rhythm. [B]Each ber always does the main melody. The voice uses its entire range from the harsh low register to the raspy high register. [B]The Lutes of Blossoming has the following structure: a passage and a finale. [B]The simple passage is moderately paced, and it is to be very soft. The passage is performed without preference for a scale and in the dab rhythm. [B]The finale is extremely fast, and it is to start loud then be immediately soft. The passage is performed using the lbu scale and in free rhythm. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1-x-x-x-x--x-xx--x-x-x-xO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The lbu hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 4th, the 6th, the 8th and the 11th. [B]The dab rhythm is made from two patterns: the ok and the ost. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The ok rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into two bars in a 4-4 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x x | - - x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The ost rhythm is a single line with five beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x X x - x | [B]where X marks an accented beat, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Verse of Droplets is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on a ber and a ostest. The musical voices cover melody, harmony and rhythm. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. The music repeats for as long as necessary. It is performed using the asmuk scale. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to make trills, add fills and alternate tension and repose. [B]The ber always should be broad and is to be moderately loud. [B]The ostest always should be broad and is to become softer and softer. [B]The Verse of Droplets has the following structure: a lengthy theme and a series of variations on the theme. [B]The theme is voiced by the melody of the ostest and the harmony of the ber. The passage is consistently slowing. The ber ranges from the harsh low register to the fragile middle register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. The passage is performed in the bor rhythm. [B]The series of variations is voiced by the melody of the ber and the rhythm of the ostest. The passage is at a walking pace. The ber ranges from the fragile middle register to the raspy high register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. The passage is performed in the nolsmu rhythm. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1-x-x-x-x--x-xx--x-x-x-xO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The asmuk hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 3rd, the 7th, the 10th and the 11th. [B]The bor rhythm is made from two patterns: the nuklat and the slulasp. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The nuklat rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into six bars in a 2-8-4-7-5-6 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | x X - x x - - x | - ! x x`| x X x - x - x | x x - X - | - - x - - - | [B]where ! marks the primary accent, X marks an accented beat, ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The slulasp rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beats are named ozse (spoken oz), slusna (slu), sasne (sa) and odu (od). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The nolsmu rhythm is made from two patterns: the urdu and the usmdas. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The urdu rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into eight bars in a 4-4-4-4-4-4-4-4 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - - - | - - x - | X x x x | x x'- - | X`x x x | X'x x x | x - x - | - x - - | [B]where X marks an accented beat, ` marks a beat as early, ' marks a beat as late, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The usmdas rhythm is a single line with five beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Silky Bewilderment is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites nonsensical words and sounds while the music is played on a ber and a ostest. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. It is performed without preference for a scale and in the agun rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to make trills, alternate tension and repose and play legato. [B]The chanter always does the main melody and should be spirited. [B]The ber always provides the rhythm and should perform sweetly. [B]The ostest always does the main melody, should be passionate and modulates frequently. [B]The Silky Bewilderment has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a lengthy verse and a lengthy chorus all repeated two times, a bridge-passage, a verse and a lengthy chorus, a lengthy bridge-passage and a finale. [B]The first verse is at a free tempo, and it is to become softer and softer. The chanter's voice ranges from the low register to the middle register and the ber covers its entire range from the harsh low register to the raspy high register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The first chorus slows and broadens, and it is to be loud. The chanter's voice stays in the low register and the ber ranges from the harsh low register to the fragile middle register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The first bridge-passage is fast, and it is to be very soft. The chanter's voice ranges from the middle register to the high register and the ber covers its entire range from the harsh low register to the raspy high register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. The passage should be composed and performed using grace notes. [B]The second verse is half the tempo of the last passage, and it is to be in whispered undertones. The chanter's voice covers its entire range and the ber stays in the harsh low register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The second chorus slows and broadens, and it is to be moderately soft. The chanter's voice ranges from the low register to the middle register and the ber ranges from the harsh low register to the fragile middle register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. [B]The second bridge-passage is at a hurried pace, and it is to be moderately soft. The chanter's voice ranges from the middle register to the high register and the ber ranges from the fragile middle register to the raspy high register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The finale is moderately paced, and it is to be moderately loud. The chanter's voice stays in the low register and the ber stays in the raspy high register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. [B]The agun rhythm is made from two patterns: the slulasp and the nuklat. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The slulasp rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beats are named ozse (spoken oz), slusna (slu), sasne (sa) and odu (od). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The nuklat rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into six bars in a 2-8-4-7-5-6 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | x X - x x - - x | - ! x x`| x X x - x - x | x x - X - | - - x - - - | [B]where ! marks the primary accent, X marks an accented beat, ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Glittery Saffron is a devotional form of music originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A singer recites nonsensical words and sounds while the music is played on a rot and a um. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance should be melancholic and is at a free tempo, and it is to start loud then be immediately soft. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. It is performed in the stotho rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to use grace notes. The voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. [B]The um always provides the rhythm. [B]The Glittery Saffron has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a verse and a lengthy chorus possibly all repeated and a coda. [B]The verse is voiced by the melody of the singer reciting nonsensical words and sounds and the rhythm of the um. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. The passage is performed using the usnusp scale. [B]The chorus is voiced by the melody of the rot and the rhythm of the um. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. The passage is performed using the ekxox scale. The passage should be composed and performed using legato. [B]The coda is voiced by the melody of the rot and the rhythm of the um. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. The passage is performed using the abo scale. The passage should be composed and performed using legato. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1-x-x-x-x--x-xx--x-x-x-xO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The usnusp hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 5th, the 7th, the 8th and the 11th. [B]The ekxox heptatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 3rd, the 4th, the 5th, the 7th and the 8th. [B]The abo heptatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 2nd, the 3rd, the 4th, the 5th, the 6th and the 7th. [B]The stotho rhythm is made from two patterns: the nuklat and the slulasp. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The nuklat rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into six bars in a 2-8-4-7-5-6 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | x X - x x - - x | - ! x x`| x X x - x - x | x x - X - | - - x - - - | [B]where ! marks the primary accent, X marks an accented beat, ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The slulasp rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beats are named ozse (spoken oz), slusna (slu), sasne (sa) and odu (od). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

dance_form.description: The Skirts of Euphoria is a group performance dance originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by The Fortuitous Smile. The dancers perform in a single line, moving to the music's lanlar rhythm. The dance is sinuous, weightless and elaborate. [B]The dance begins with the introduction of the music. The dancers perform slowly with the music. This fluid section is punctuated by clockwise half turns, spins and sensual hand gestures, with movement performed in succession by group members. [B]The dance enters a new section with the bridge-passage of the music. The dancers perform faster and faster with the music. This section is punctuated by grotesque leaps. [B]The dance enters a new section with the variations on the theme of the music. The dancers perform very quickly with the music. This section is punctuated by serene hand gestures and sluggish clockwise eighth turns.

The Aquamarine of Intricacies is a war dance originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by The Mauve Flutes. The dancers perform in a single line, moving quickly with the music. The crude aggressive dance is punctuated by passionate right kicks, intense leaps and vigorous independent body movement, with large moves.

The Tenebrous Lyric is a social partner dance originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by The Fortuitous Smile. The dancers perform in a double circle, moving to the music's lanlar rhythm. The dance is punctuated by aborted backward bends and large footwork. [B]The dance begins with the introduction of the music. The dancers perform slowly with the music. The partners maintain open contact, communicating intent by pulling away. This undulating elaborate section is punctuated by strong hand gestures. [B]The dance enters a new section with the theme of the music. The dancers perform slower and slower with the music. The partners dance closely, communicating intent by pulling away briefly. This section is punctuated by crude right kicks, the sluggish counterclockwise half turns of the lead and straight-lined hand gestures. [B]The dance enters a new section with the bridge-passage of the music. The dancers perform faster and faster with the music. The partners dance closely, communicating intent by pushing together. This section is graceful and passionate. [B]The dance enters a new section with the variations on the theme of the music. The dancers perform very quickly with the music. The partners dance closely, communicating intent by pushing together constantly. This sinuous delicate section is punctuated by the repeated right kicks of the lead and spins.

The Glosses of Quiescence is a war dance originating in The Dented Merchant. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by The Mauve Flutes. The dancers perform loosely mingled, moving quickly with the music. The spirited dance is punctuated by spins and grotesque footwork.

The Lute of Sparkling is a performance partner dance originating in The Dented Merchant. The rules of the form are applied by choreographers to produce individual dances which can be performed. The dance is accompanied by The Fortuitous Smile. The dancers perform in several lines, moving to the music's lanlar rhythm. The partners maintain open contact, communicating intent by pulling away. This dance is a refined artform, with one special position and three specific moves to be mastered. The jerking dance is punctuated by passionate clockwise quarter turns. [B]The dance begins with the introduction of the music. The dancers perform slowly with the music. This sharp-edged section is punctuated by the expressive independent body movement of the lead, spirited body level changes and expressive raised right arms. [B]The dance enters a new section with the theme of the music. The dancers perform slower and slower with the music. This section is punctuated by raised arms. [B]The dance enters a new section with the bridge-passage of the music. The dancers perform faster and faster with the music. This sensual section is punctuated by the passionate curved walks of the lead and intense leg lifts. [B]The dance enters a new section with the variations on the theme of the music. The dancers perform very quickly with the music. This expressive lively section is punctuated by the passionate hand gestures of the lead and the sensual body level changes of the lead. [B]The nural the fundamental dance position. There should be a joyous hand gesture from the lead. [B]The bugsud is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is flamboyant footwork. [B]The okag is one of the fundamental dance moves. First, there is a kick from the follower. Then there is a softly percussive straight walk. [B]The nazush is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is a crude forward bend.

The Tulips of Glossing is a solo performance dance originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by any composition of The Lutes of Blossoming. The proud dance is punctuated by sluggish hand gestures, elaborate footwork and strong straight walks. [B]The dance begins with the passage of the music. The dancer performs to the dab rhythm. There is a basic movement called the osm. There is a series of four softly percussive steps in a figure-eight pattern. This section is punctuated by sluggish arm carriage, sway and spirited raised left arms. [B]The dance enters a new section with the finale of the music. The dancer performs very quickly with the music. This section is punctuated by debauched independent body movement and leg lifts.

The Chartreuse Veneration is a solo performance dance originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by any composition of The Verse of Droplets. The dancer performs along an improvised path. The weightless elaborate dance is punctuated by loudly percussive runs. [B]The dance enters a new section with the variations on the theme of the music. The dancer performs slowly to the nolsmu rhythm. This section is punctuated by fluid movement along the line of dance.

The Berry of Cherishing is a sacred solo dance originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by any composition of The Glittery Saffron. This dance is a refined artform, with two special positions to be mastered. The crude dance is punctuated by spins and powerful leaps. [B]The dance begins with the verse of the music. This section is punctuated by vivacious left kicks. [B]The dance enters a new section with the chorus of the music. This section is punctuated by independent body movement. [B]The dance enters a new section with the coda of the music. This section is punctuated by flamboyant forward bends. [B]The enu is one of the fundamental dance positions. There should be a partially realized hand gesture. [B]The stl is one of the fundamental dance positions. There should be a straight-lined raised arm with a straight-lined forward bend and a strong hand gesture.

The Satin of Droplets is a social partner dance originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by any composition of The Silky Bewilderment. The dancers perform in a circle, moving to the music's agun rhythm. The partners rarely make contact, communicating intent constantly through visual cues. The entire dance has a basic movement called the zak. There is a series of sixteen subtle steps in a figure-eight pattern with an elaborate hand gesture and a subtle clockwise eighth half turn. The dance is punctuated by undulating independent body movement. [B]The dance begins with the verse of the music. This vigorous aggressive refined section is punctuated by sensual raised arms and the spirited sway of the follower. [B]The dance enters a new section with the chorus of the music. The dancers perform slower and slower with the music. This section is punctuated by softly percussive runs and low body level. [B]The dance enters a new section with the bridge-passage of the music. The dancers perform quickly with the music. This grotesque passionate section is punctuated by the spins of the lead. [B]The dance enters a new section with the next verse of the music. The dancers perform slowly with the music. This sprightly section is punctuated by low body level. [B]The dance enters a new section with the next chorus of the music. The dancers perform slower and slower with the music. This section is elaborate and flamboyant. [B]The dance enters a new section with the next bridge-passage of the music. The dancers perform quickly with the music. This section is punctuated by vivacious runs. [B]The dance enters a new section with the finale of the music. This section is punctuated by spirited raised left arms and the high kicks of the follower.

The Chartreuse Poem is a sacred solo dance originating in The Jackal of Shadows. The form guides dancers during improvised performances. The dance is accompanied by any composition of The Glittery Saffron. This dance is a refined artform, with five specific moves to be mastered. The entire dance has a basic movement called the tuxxu. There is a series of sixteen steps in a square pattern with an elaborate hand gesture, a debauched backward bend and a debauched facial expression. The soft dance is punctuated by straight walks and leaps. [B]The dance begins with the verse of the music. This section is punctuated by debauched spins. [B]The dance enters a new section with the chorus of the music. This undulating section is punctuated by partially realized moves. [B]The dance enters a new section with the coda of the music. This section is punctuated by independent body movement and sinuous runs. [B]The ugas is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is a grotesque raised left arm with delicate footwork and a subtle sway. [B]The ustrok is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is a low raised left arm with independent body movement and a spin. [B]The gosma is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is a run with a low body level and a sprightly arm carriage. [B]The kbu is one of the fundamental dance moves. First, there is a leap with a clockwise eighth quarter turn, independent body movement and a left kick. Then there is a grotesque left leg lift with a refined clockwise eighth quarter turn. Then there is a straight walk with an elaborate leftward bend. Finally, there is a low leap with a counterclockwise eighth quarter turn, independent body movement and an elaborate arm carriage. [B]The ron is one of the fundamental dance moves. There is a subtle run with a rightward bend.
